subject: Update : EEPROM device type identification logic.

comments.message:
Patch Set 7: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start

Patch Set 7: Verified+1

Build Successful 

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/47905/ : SUCCESS

Given that the 'master' branch reference (and lines numbers in it) may change over time, it would be more future-proof to link to the line within a specific revision (e.g. https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/9dc2cc5387bb2902128a26d8426d99fc1aee8854/src/FruDevice.cpp#L197), or perhaps just to the commit that introduced that code (https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/commit/2d681f6fdec02b2f56d9155117c4830703026cb0).
I have no interest in supporting per-machine services in entity-manager.  If you need a per-machine service, write an entity-manager reactor, which can be be per-machine.

If I understood your statement properly i could think of following design:

Just creating a new reactor deamon in entity-manager, through this reactor deamon will read and parse the ncsi command and get the output as 8-bit or 16-bit. Then it will update the 8-bit or 16 bit device byte type in Dbus interfaces of FRU device and read from it.

Question:Is it fine to have the deamon(detector EEPROM) in entity-manager?

> If I understood your statement properly i could think of following design:
> 
> Just creating a new reactor deamon in entity-manager,

It would not belong in entity-manager.  Entity-manager is for common code.

> through this reactor deamon will read and parse the ncsi command and get the output as 8-bit or 16-bit.

AH, now I understand.  Let me make sure I have it right.

1. BMC reads the NCSI ID of the NIC
2. The NCSI id will determine if the NIC has a 16 bit or 8 bit eeprom


That makes more sense.  In that case, your flow would be:

1. Update NCSId to expose an appropriate dbus API for determining the "model" or "ID" of the card.  You might need to invent a new interface here.
2. Write an EM config file that uses that dbus API for its probe statement.
3. In the EM config file, add a "Size" flag under the Type: "EEPROM" field.
4. Update FruDevice to check EM configs, and lookup the size field appropriately if it's defined in an EM config.


The advantage of the above design is that there's no new platform-specific code, and it's reusing most of the infrastructure that exists already.

> Then it will update the 8-bit or 16 bit device byte type in Dbus interfaces of FRU device and read from it.
> 
> Question:Is it fine to have the deamon(detector EEPROM) in entity-manager?

In the above what I've written, there are no new daemons here.

NCSID exists (although would need to be promoted out of the meta-google repo if more people are going to use it)
https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-google/recipes-google/ncsi/ncsid_git.bb

That would be the thing that exposes the NCSI device model number.

ack.This flow would be good, we can get the eeprom single byte or two byte by using get info or get version command from ncsid.

dbus api can be created for this ncsid and it can be probed by entity-manager config, and fru device can the eeprom type.
Please avoid making this a script.  They are difficult to debug and maintain over time.
Ack.Based on the first review comment input/suggestions this can be concluded.

I'm not following this step.  If you don't know if the eeprom is 8 bit or 16 bit, how does this script suddenly bypass the "detect 16 bit eeprom" problem?  Won't this script have the same issue as the FruDevice code does?

The script doesn't read the EEPROM directly, There are some other mechanism to find out whether this will have a 8-bit or 16-bit EEPROM. this will read by the NIC manufacturer information using nisi command, using this command ncsi-netlink --info -x 2 -p 0 -c 0  will get the output like this 

Get Info , PACKAGE :  0, IFINDEX :  2
Package has id : 0
Channel Active : 0
Channel Major Version : f1f1f000
Channel Minor Version : 0
Channel Version Str :mlx0.1
Channel Link State : 2f
Active Vlan ids

based on this information, we are getting 8 bit or 16 bit type using manufacturer information
Now I understand.  See my reply on the previous comment about how you could make this work in an entity-manager system.

To repeat, if you want a platform-specific service, write and maintain a platform specific service.  Dbus is your extension point and interface there;  If you want to reuse code from FruDevice for it, abstract it to a library (a lot of that work has already been done).  I'm not interested in having a plugin system for FruDevice, which is intended to be self-contained.
Ack.Based on the first review comment input/suggestions this can be concluded.

In this flow, you've basically described how this should work, you've just added a number of pieces that are extra and not needed.

1. In the "Type": "eeprom" entry for a given device, include a parameter called "size" that can determine whether the eeprom is 16 bit or 8 bit.
2. Determine how to detect the "is 16 bit" of a given device without pre-defined knowledge of said device, or attach the relevant information to the baseboard configuration for something like "Eeprom hint"
3. Add the backward path to FruDevice such that FruDevice looks at the size parameter, and uses that to set the 16bitness of the part.

We have a json file for baseboard FRU and we have a separate json file for each NIC card in entity-manager, if particular  NIC card has been detected then it will load the corresponding json config file and read the EEPROM information, EEPROM config can be detected at run time based on the loaded FRU NIC.

we have a NIC card slot, that will support Mellanox NIC card or Broadcom NIC card, Both are having different EEPROM configuration. we have to detect 8-bit or 16-bit EEPROM type before load the FRU NIC. This EEPROM byte detection is platform specific.

> We have a json file for baseboard FRU and we have a separate json file for each NIC card in entity-manager, if particular  NIC card has been detected then it will load the corresponding json config file and read the EEPROM information, EEPROM config can be detected at run time based on the loaded FRU NIC.

Yep, you got it.

> 
> we have a NIC card slot, that will support Mellanox NIC card or Broadcom NIC card, Both are having different EEPROM configuration. we have to detect 8-bit or 16-bit EEPROM type before load the FRU NIC.

Slight change in wording: You have to detect the MODEL of the card.  From there entity-manager can generally configure the size of the eeprom, which doesn't need to be platform specific.

> This EEPROM byte detection is platform specific.

IMO, based on what you've written, I don't think it is.  If I put a 16 bit eeprom mellonox card into any system, I'd like it to parse correctly, and using NCSI seems like a nice generic way to do that model detection.
ack. As per flow what you are suggest, this will be generic way to detect the model ID in ncsid.
nit, you might want to call this a "NIC".  FRU implies that it's the eeprom.

Question: it's pretty clear that this code doesn't work as designed, and the original author has stated that it doesn't work for their use case.  Could this detection logic be completely removed as part of this work?
Yes, This will be removed as per our implementation.
This needs to be discuss with original author and we need to remove it, and how come they are approved it ?
Nit, please use specific models of eeprom.  "two byte eeprom" isn't very descriptive.
Can we call out that this is a "size" and not a "type".  eeprom size has other uses, like properly populating a FRU SDR, that we'd also like to solve eventually.

This seems redundant to the second sentence of #1.  Also, the dbus API is not going to detect the eeprom byte type, it's going to detect the MODEL of the card.  EM will expose the eeprom size from its known card types.

Also, doesn't this code belong in ncsid?  I thought that phosphor-network was for managing the network devices, not handling NCSI devices.
ncsid is the separate daemon,So posed a question in mailing list to the community, to change that ncsid bin into service to expose D-bus.
fork and exec should be avoided in applications.  Can this data be gotten directly in-process without invoking another one?
This doesn't seem right.  The NCSI device isn't going to directly identify the EEPROM size, that will happen in EM, right?
The NCSI command only determine the eeprom size and that size will be updated in D-bus. EM just read from it.
Would like more details on what this looks like.  I suspect this is just adding "Size" to the existing eeprom interface, but that should be called out here.

Hi All,
These are the implementation patches have been uploaded for NIC EEPROM byte size 
identification as single byte (Broadcom) or two byte (Mellanox), please refer to below link.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/52480
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/+/52478
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/52473
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/52452

Hai all,
please review the patch and provide your suggestions.
Thanks
Please ack and/or resolve the comment from Zev so this task can move forward.  There has been no movement on this commit in over a week.
Please line wrap with a tool.  This looks like it was line wrapped by hand on <80 character boundaries.
This is a good succinct problem description.  Good work.

While this is a long link, personally I think it would be better to leave it as one line instead of wrapping it.

However, it's also now out of date -- see commit f805bafb4dacc629c2b7da0fda90f3fd950d9b07.  Have you tested with that change incorporated to see if it already handles the problem you're aiming to solve here?

with the latest code I have tested in our platform , but it doesn't work and trying ti fix it,
or else we can continue with this implementation?

that decision is up to you.  If the newest patchset doesn't solve your problem, then yes, maybe this design is still warranted.


As far as the link, can we just avoid it, and just call out the name of the funtion, isDevice16Bit()

Does phosphor-networkd have existing ncsi code?  I would've kind of expected this to be a new daemon, probably starting with ncsid from google-misc (or not, up for discussion).  phosphor-networkd seems like it mostly contains code for interacting with systemd.
This is confusing.  phosphor-networkd is a service, maybe you mean phosphor-networkd the repo?  Please clarify in your doc.
Nit, this deamon would identify NIC MODEL, not eeprom size directly.  that would then be matched up with an EM config where we set the eeprom size.

Please don't launch an application like this directly.  Either rely directly on sysfs, or use a library.  Execing applications from within another application is error prone, especially when it comes to debugging errors.

[Unit]
Description=NIC card informations
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/env phosphor-ncsi-info
Restart=always
SyslogIdentifier=phosphor-ncsi-info
Type=dbus
BusName=@BUSNAME@
[Install]
WantedBy=@SYSTEMD_TARGET@

This is a separate process, I think it doesn't affect the 
existing process. So there is no application collision error.

> This is a separate process

Right, that's part of the problem.  The common process is

kernel -> sysfs -> <optional> library -> openbmc daemon.

Calling command line applications and trying to read data out of them is error prone.  Please rely on the underlying implementation that CLI uses.
This is good, and in line with what I would expect.

This requires phosphor-networkd to have a per-component lookup, and keep a table of all possible models.   That's not really what phosphor-networkd is for, that's what EM is for, because it's trivial to add new models, and to parse which models are currently supported.
Again, this doesn't work, because now your probe can't differentiate between different models of card.
Good, this section looks correct to me.
There are still several unresolved comments.  Is there anything blocking them from being resolved?
Please fix line wrapping throughout.  You are making me put in extra effort to even read this.
Can this be explained?  I don't know what you are getting at.
I would suggest this immediately after the "But, this implementation..." sentence.  This is the evidence for the statement you are making, so put them together.
Is this a new daemon or integrated into an existing one?
I'm not seeing this as resolved in this patchset.

Is manufacturer permanently sufficient for this determination?  What happens if Broadcom starts using 2-byte NICs in the future?  What if they supply a different part to different companies and only the Meta NIC is 1-byte?  Is there really some model checks that should be done here?

This sounds different from #3.

Are we doing a Probe on a Manufacturer/Model pair that is exposed by phopshor-networkd, or are we doing a Probe on some "EEPROM Size" property?  #3 implies "EEPROM size" but #4 implies Manufacturer/Model pair.
